 ## Details
 
-🚧 **Under construction** 🚧
+For configurations with a specified schema, create a subclass of [`ConfigDataclass`][fancy_dataclass.config.ConfigDataclass] instantiating your schema.
 
-<!--
-- By default ConfigDataclass cannot write config files, only read them. To write, subclass JSONDataclass or TOMLDataclass.
-- Structured vs. unstructured configs
- -->
+The following methods can then be used:
+
+- [`load_config`][fancy_dataclass.config.FileConfig.load_config]: load configs from a JSON or TOML file
+- [`get_config`][fancy_dataclass.config.Config.get_config]: get the global config object
+- [`clear_config`][fancy_dataclass.config.Config.clear_config]: set the global config to `None`
+- [`update_config`][fancy_dataclass.config.Config.update_config]: set the global config to a particular object
+- [`as_config`][fancy_dataclass.config.Config.as_config]: context manager to temporarily change the global config to a particular object
+
+For configurations _without_ a specified schema, you can use [`DictConfig`][fancy_dataclass.config.DictConfig] instead. This has the same interface as `ConfigDataclass`, except you do not need to subclass it or specify a dataclass schema. Instead, it can load the contents of a JSON or TOML file into a regular Python dict, which you can access with `get_config`.
+
+By default, `ConfigDataclass` and `DictConfig` cannot write config files, only read them. To write, you can subclass [`JSONDataclass`](json.md) or [`TOMLDataclass`](toml.md).

 ## Details
 
-🚧 **Under construction** 🚧
+`TOMLDataclass` inherits from [`DictDataclass`][fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclass], which can be used to convert dataclasses to/from Python dicts via [`to_dict`][fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclass.to_dict] and [`from_dict`][fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclass.from_dict]. You may use `DictDataclass` if you do not need to interact with TOML serialized data.
 
-<!--
-- TOML is more of a config format than a storage format
-- Unlike JSONDataclass, defaults are not suppressed by default, but can set `suppress_defaults=True`
- -->
+### Class and Field Settings
+
+The class and field settings for `TOMLDataclass` are identical to those for [`JSONDataclass`](json.md#class-and-field-settings). See [`DictDataclassSettings`][fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclassSettings] for the list of class settings, and [`DictDataclassFieldSettings`][fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclassFieldSettings] for the list of field-specific settings.
+
+TOML is intended as more of a configuration format than a data storage format. Consequently, unlike `JSONDataclass`, `TOMLDataclass` does not suppress default field values in its output by default. To opt into this behavior, you can set the class setting `suppress_defaults=True`.

+</ul>

+<h3 id="changed_1">Changed</h3>

 <h2 id="details">Details</h2>
-<p>🚧 <strong>Under construction</strong> 🚧</p>
-<!--
-- By default ConfigDataclass cannot write config files, only read them. To write, subclass JSONDataclass or TOMLDataclass.
-- Structured vs. unstructured configs
- -->
-
+<p>For configurations with a specified schema, create a subclass of <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/config.html#fancy_dataclass.config.ConfigDataclass"><code>ConfigDataclass</code></a> instantiating your schema.</p>
+<p>The following methods can then be used:</p>
+<ul>
+<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/config.html#fancy_dataclass.config.FileConfig.load_config"><code>load_config</code></a>: load configs from a JSON or TOML file</li>
+<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/config.html#fancy_dataclass.config.Config.get_config"><code>get_config</code></a>: get the global config object</li>
+<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/config.html#fancy_dataclass.config.Config.clear_config"><code>clear_config</code></a>: set the global config to <code>None</code></li>
+<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/config.html#fancy_dataclass.config.Config.update_config"><code>update_config</code></a>: set the global config to a particular object</li>
+<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/config.html#fancy_dataclass.config.Config.as_config"><code>as_config</code></a>: context manager to temporarily change the global config to a particular object</li>
+</ul>
+<p>For configurations <em>without</em> a specified schema, you can use <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/config.html#fancy_dataclass.config.DictConfig"><code>DictConfig</code></a> instead. This has the same interface as <code>ConfigDataclass</code>, except you do not need to subclass it or specify a dataclass schema. Instead, it can load the contents of a JSON or TOML file into a regular Python dict, which you can access with <code>get_config</code>.</p>
+<p>By default, <code>ConfigDataclass</code> and <code>DictConfig</code> cannot write config files, only read them. To write, you can subclass <a href="json.html"><code>JSONDataclass</code></a> or <a href="toml.html"><code>TOMLDataclass</code></a>.</p>

 <h1 id="basics">Basics</h1>
 <p>🤵🏻‍♂️ <strong><em>Fancy Dataclass</em></strong>: A library to spiff up your dataclasses with extra features.</p>
 <h2 id="introduction">Introduction</h2>
 <p>Python 3.7 introduced the <code>dataclasses</code> module which lets you write "statically typed" classes using the type hinting mechanism.</p>
 <p>By inspecting dataclasses' type annotations, it is possible to endow them with special powers that help cut down on boilerplate code in a wide variety of domains, such as:</p>
 <ul>
 <li><em>JSON/TOML conversion</em>: convert dataclasses to JSON/TOML files and vice versa</li>

-<p>The <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/json.html#fancy_dataclass.json.JSONDataclass"><code>JSONDataclass</code></a> mixin provides automatic conversion to and from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JSON">JSON</a>.</p>

-<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/json.html#fancy_dataclass.json.JSONSerializable.to_json"><code>to_json</code></a> / <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/json.html#fancy_dataclass.json.JSONSerializable.from_json"><code>from_json</code></a> convert to and from a JSON file-like object.</li>

+<p>Python's <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html"><code>subprocess</code></a> module is commonly used to call other programs from within Python.</p>
+<p>The <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/subprocess.html#fancy_dataclass.subprocess.SubprocessDataclass"><code>SubprocessDataclass</code></a> mixin provides a simple wrapper for <code>subprocess.run</code> which builds up the argument list automatically from a dataclass's fields. This can be useful in at least two ways:</p>
+<ol>
+<li>Cuts down the boilerplate of handling argument names and string conversions.</li>
+<li>Can improve security if you add field validation before passing values to <code>subprocess.run</code>.</li>
+</ol>

-<li><code>JSONDataclass</code> is configured to use the default JSON settings provided by Python's standard <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/json.html"><code>json</code></a> library. This allows out-of-range float values like <code>nan</code> and <code>inf</code> to be represented as <code>NaN</code> and <code>Infinity</code>, which are not strictly part of the JSON standard. To disallow these values, you can pass <code>allow_nan=False</code> when calling <code>to_json</code> or <code>to_json_string</code>, which will raise a <code>ValueError</code> if such values occur.</li>

+Python's _s_u_b_p_r_o_c_e_s_s module is commonly used to call other programs from within
+Python.
+The _S_u_b_p_r_o_c_e_s_s_D_a_t_a_c_l_a_s_s mixin provides a simple wrapper for subprocess.run
+which builds up the argument list automatically from a dataclass's fields. This
+can be useful in at least two ways:
+   1. Cuts down the boilerplate of handling argument names and string
+      conversions.
+   2. Can improve security if you add field validation before passing values to
+      subprocess.run.

+class ListDir(SubprocessDataclass, exec='ls'):  # specify program to run
+    """Lists directory contents."""
+    # list in long form
+    long: bool = field(
+        default=False,
+        metadata={'args': '-l'}
+    )
+    # list in reverse order
+    reverse: bool = field(
+        default=False,
+        metadata={'args': '-r'}
+    )
+    # sort by time
+    time: bool = field(
+        default=False,
+        metadata={'args': '-t'}
+    )
+    # name of directory to list
+    dir_name: str = field(
+        default='.',
+        metadata={'args': ''}
+    )
+Set up a test directory with an example file.
+from pathlib import Path
+

+test_dir.mkdir()

-  <h1>Subprocess calls</h1>
+  <h1>TOML conversion</h1>
 
 <!-- markdownlint-disable MD052 -->
 
-<p>Python's <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html"><code>subprocess</code></a> module is commonly used to call other programs from within Python.</p>
-<p>The <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/subprocess.html#fancy_dataclass.subprocess.SubprocessDataclass"><code>SubprocessDataclass</code></a> mixin provides a simple wrapper for <code>subprocess.run</code> which builds up the argument list automatically from a dataclass's fields. This can be useful in at least two ways:</p>
-<ol>
-<li>Cuts down the boilerplate of handling argument names and string conversions.</li>
-<li>Can improve security if you add field validation before passing values to <code>subprocess.run</code>.</li>
-</ol>
+<p>The <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLDataclass"><code>TOMLDataclass</code></a> mixin provides automatic conversion to and from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TOML">TOML</a>. This uses the <a href="https://tomlkit.readthedocs.io"><code>tomlkit</code></a> library under the hood.</p>
+<ul>
+<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/dict.html#fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclass.to_dict"><code>to_dict</code></a> / <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/dict.html#fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclass.from_dict"><code>from_dict</code></a> convert to and from Python dicts.</li>
+<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLSerializable.to_toml"><code>to_toml</code></a> / <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLSerializable.from_toml"><code>from_toml</code></a> convert to and from TOML file-like objects.</li>
+<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/serialize.html#fancy_dataclass.serialize.FileSerializable.save"><code>save</code></a> / <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/serialize.html#fancy_dataclass.serialize.FileSerializable.load"><code>load</code></a> convert to and from a TOML file-like object or path.</li>
+<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLSerializable.to_toml_string"><code>to_toml_string</code></a> / <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLSerializable.from_toml_string"><code>from_toml_string</code></a> convert to and from TOML strings.</li>
+</ul>
 <h2 id="usage-example">Usage Example</h2>
-<p>Define a <code>SubprocessDataclass</code> to delegate calls to command-line programs within Python.</p>
-<div class="language-python highlight"><pre><span></span><code><span id="__span-0-1"><a id="__codelineno-0-1" name="__codelineno-0-1" href="#__codelineno-0-1"></a><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">dataclasses</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">dataclass</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">field</span>

+<p><code>TOMLDataclass</code> inherits from <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/dict.html#fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclass"><code>DictDataclass</code></a>, which can be used to convert dataclasses to/from Python dicts via <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/dict.html#fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclass.to_dict"><code>to_dict</code></a> and <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/dict.html#fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclass.from_dict"><code>from_dict</code></a>. You may use <code>DictDataclass</code> if you do not need to interact with TOML serialized data.</p>
+<h3 id="class-and-field-settings">Class and Field Settings</h3>
+<p>The class and field settings for <code>TOMLDataclass</code> are identical to those for <a href="json.html#class-and-field-settings"><code>JSONDataclass</code></a>. See <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/dict.html#fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclassSettings"><code>DictDataclassSettings</code></a> for the list of class settings, and <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/dict.html#fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclassFieldSettings"><code>DictDataclassFieldSettings</code></a> for the list of field-specific settings.</p>
+<p>TOML is intended as more of a configuration format than a data storage format. Consequently, unlike <code>JSONDataclass</code>, <code>TOMLDataclass</code> does not suppress default field values in its output by default. To opt into this behavior, you can set the class setting <code>suppress_defaults=True</code>.</p>

-<p>The <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLDataclass"><code>TOMLDataclass</code></a> mixin provides automatic conversion to and from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TOML">TOML</a>. This uses the <a href="https://tomlkit.readthedocs.io"><code>tomlkit</code></a> library under the hood.</p>
-<ul>
-<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/dict.html#fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclass.to_dict"><code>to_dict</code></a> / <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/dict.html#fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclass.from_dict"><code>from_dict</code></a> convert to and from Python dicts.</li>
-<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLSerializable.to_toml"><code>to_toml</code></a> / <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLSerializable.from_toml"><code>from_toml</code></a> convert to and from TOML file-like objects.</li>
-<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/serialize.html#fancy_dataclass.serialize.FileSerializable.save"><code>save</code></a> / <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/serialize.html#fancy_dataclass.serialize.FileSerializable.load"><code>load</code></a> convert to and from a TOML file-like object or path.</li>
-<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLSerializable.to_toml_string"><code>to_toml_string</code></a> / <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLSerializable.from_toml_string"><code>from_toml_string</code></a> convert to and from TOML strings.</li>
-</ul>

 <p>Per-field settings can be passed into the <code>metadata</code> argument of each <code>dataclasses.field</code>. See <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="#fancy_dataclass.sql.SQLDataclassFieldSettings"><code>SQLDataclassFieldSettings</code></a> for the full list of settings.</p>
 <p>All dataclass fields will correspond to SQL columns unless their metadata is marked with <code>sql=False</code>.</p>
 <p>Each field may also contain a <code>"column"</code> entry in its <code>metadata</code> dict. This will provide optional keyword arguments to be passed to sqlalchemy's <a href="https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/core/metadata.html#sqlalchemy.schema.Column"><code>Column</code></a> constructor.</p>
 <p>Some types are invalid for SQL columns; if such a type occurs, a <code>TypeError</code> will be raised.</p>

+    @dataclass

+    check_invalid_args(DCDouble, ['cmd0'], 'arguments are required: subcommand')
